Award.AwardTitle: CRII: SaTC: Automated Security Analysis of Software-Based Control in Emerging Smart Transportation Under Sensor Attacks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Transportation systems are being profoundly transformed with the emergence of a series of software-based smart transportation solutions such as intelligent traffic signal control and autonomous driving. In these systems, the key enabler of their functional intelligence is the sensing capability, which collects necessary road information to enable better control decisions. However, sensor data are collected from a public channel, i.e., the physical transportation environment, which thus inevitably creates opportunities for attackers to tamper with the sensing process. In this project, the investigator initiates research efforts towards achieving a systematic understanding of the robustness of software-based control in emerging smart transportation systems under sensor attacks. Since transportation is a basic urban function, the successful completion of this project is expected to proactively identify and address new security challenges in these systems before wide deployment, and thus help ensure the security and safety of everyday life.

In this project, an automatic approach will be designed, implemented, and evaluated to enable efficient and effective discovery of security problems in emerging smart transportation systems. The approach focuses on discovering semantic security problems, which for example change control decisions in the smart transportation functions. This is because analyzing them usually leads to the discovery of novel and domain-specific design trade-offs in an area or even across areas, which thus has more potential to advance knowledge and guide future research. To achieve this goal, this project will design a dynamic security analysis system following an evolutionary algorithm approach, and propose novel solutions to address research challenges in analysis input generation, semantic problem discovery, and analyzing dataflow-centric decision process. This project will concretely apply the developed system to real-world code bases of smart transportation systems to ensure the practicality of the discovered security problems, challenges, and solution directions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project successfully initiated the first systematic research effort towards understanding the security of the autonomy software stack in Connected Vehicle (CV) and Autonomous Driving (AD) systems under physical-layer attacks. On the intellectual merit side, this project performed the first security analysis for (1) various critical AI (Artificial Intelligence) algorithms in industry-grade AD context, e.g., LiDAR perception, object tracking, localization, lane detection, multi-sensor fusion (for both perception and localiazation), and traffic light detection; (2) CV protocols and applications, such as latest P2PCD and platoon management protocols, and CV-based traffic signal control systems under black-box attack settings; and (3) new over-the-air attack surface in automotive IoT such as the popular wireless OBD-II dongles today.

To perform systematic analysis, this project made various methodology-level contributions such as new optimization-based attack generation methods for various physical-layer attack vectors such as LiDAR spoofing, dirty road patches, and adversarial 3D obstacles (such as maliciously-shaped traffic cone or rock); novel stealthy and opportunistic GPS spoofing attack method for multi-sensor fusion based AD localization; novel ROI attack design to trigger traffic light misdetection by attacking localization; new black-box attack method for CV-based traffic signal control systems using a novel surrogate model design; new rigorous model-checking methods to automatically discover denial-of-service vulnerabilities in CV protocols and applications; and new CAN bus command reverse-engineering method leveraging companion smartphone apps. These efforts led to 7 top-tier conference publications in the security community (1 * IEEE S&P, 3* Usenix Security, 1 * ACM CCS, and 1 * ISOC NDSS) and the transportation community (1 * TRB). Collection of these efforts are on the project website: https://sites.google.com/view/cav-sec.

On the broader impacts side, this project made significant impacts to education/training, academic community, and the society through: (1) New course and course materials, including 1 new graduate-level course and new course materials on AD, AI, and CV security in both undergraduate- and graduate-level security courses at UCI; (2) Research mentoring, for 3 Ph.D. students, 2 M.S. students, and 15 B.S. students at UCI in total; (3) Undergraduate security competition adivsing, for a team of 7 B.S. students; (4) New academic workshop organizing, for example co-founding the AutoSec (Automotive and Autonomous Vehicle Security) Workshop in 2019 and co-chairing it annually, and co-chairing the IEEE SafeThings Workshop in 2021; (5) New security competition organizing, for example the first AutoDriving CTF (Capture-The-Flag) competition in 2021 at DEFCON (one of the world's largest and most notable hacker convention); (6) Media coverage, for example by Forbes; (7) Invited talks at various academia conferences, unversities, and industry companies, including a keynote at CPSS'21; and (8) Source code/data release, all on https://github.com/ASGuard-UCI.

For all the security vulnerabilities discovered in this project, the PI performed extensive responsible vulnerability disclosure to potentailly affected industry developers/companies related to AD and CV. These efforts led to significant industry impacts, for example (1) triggered over 25 AD companies to start investigating the security vulnerabilities newly-discovered in this project, among which some companies confirmed to work on fixes; (2) proposed CV protocol vulnerabilities mitigation solutions to IEEE 1609 Working Group, which are planned to be integrated into the next version of IEEE 1609.2; (3) obtained 4 CVEs (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) for the newly-discovered authentication vulnerabilities in various wireless OBD-II dongles such as Carly, LELink, FIXD, Carista, etc.; and (4) invited to perform vulnerability disclosure at Auto-ISAC (Automotive Information Sharing & Analysis Center), which has 50+ company members including light- and heavy-duty vehicle OEMs, suppliers and the commercial vehicle sector.

Due to the signifcant intellectual merit and broader impacts above, this project led to various awards: (1) Best Technical Poster Award (top 1/30) at ISOC NDSS 2020, a top-tier security conference; (2) Distinguished Poster Presentation Award (top 2/36) at ISOC NDSS 2019, a top-tier security conference; (3) UCI Chancellor’s Award for Excellence in Undergraduate Research (only 1 student per school), to Kanglan Tang (BS'21); (4) 1st place (Gold Medal) on CCDC (CollegiateCyber Defense Competition) Western Regional, advanced to National CCDC for the first time, and ended up 5th place out of 168+ university/college teams nationwideat National CCDC; (5) 1st place (champion) in the world's first AutoDriving Security CTF competition; and (6) Most Amusing Award and Most Engaging Award (both top 1/17) at 2019 USENIX Summit on Hot Topics in Security (HotSec ’19).
